{{Infobox person | name = Marcela Mariño de Agoncillo | image = Marcela_de_Agoncillo.png | image_size = 150px | caption = | birth_name = Marcela Mariño y Coronel | birth_date = June 24, 1860 | birth_place = [[Taal, Batangas|Taal]], [[Batangas]], [[Captaincy General of the Philippines]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1946|05|30|1860|06|24}} | death_place = [[Manila]], [[Commonwealth of the Philippines]] | death_cause = | resting_place = [[La Loma Cemetery]] | resting_place_coordinates = | residence = Taal Batangas <small>(ancestral home)</small> and Malate Manila <small>(family)</small> | nationality = [[Filipino people|Filipino]] | other_names = Doña Marcela, Lola Celay | known_for = Her legacy as the principle seamstress of the first and official [[Philippine flag]] | education = | occupation = | religion = | spouse = [[Felipe Agoncillo|Don Felipe Agoncillo]] | partner = | children = [[Lorenza Agoncillo|Lorenza]], Gregoria, Eugenia, Marcela, Adela and Maria | parents = Francisco Mariño and Eugenia Coronel | relatives = | signature = }}
'''Marcela Mariño de Agoncillo''' (née '''Mariño y Coronel'''; June 24, 1860 – May 30, 1946),<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mc.edu.ph/library/avinfo.asp?strSearch=&nType=3&nResourceID=1000008522 |title=Miriam College Library |accessdate=2007-11-21 |publisher=''Mc.edu.ph''}}</ref><ref name="MMA">{{Citation |last=Mercado |first=Monina A. |publication-date=1977 |title=Profiles in Achievement |publication-place= |publisher=Philippine Appliance Corp. |page=58 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NQ08AAAAMAAJ&dq=Marcela+Agoncillo+daughter+of+rich+family&q=Marcela+Agoncillo |accessdate=2007-11-29 |year=1977}}</ref> also simply known as '''Marcela Agoncillo''', was a [[Filipino people|Filipina]] renowned in [[History of the Philippines|Philippine history]] as the principal seamstress of the first and official [[flag of the Philippines]],<ref name="TPR">{{Citation |publication-date=1969 |title=The Philippine Revolution |publication-place= |publisher=Sunday Times Magazine |page=15 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iMEmAAAAMAAJ&dq=Marcela+Agoncillo&q=Marcela+Agoncillo |accessdate=2007-11-29 |year=1969}}</ref> gaining her the title of Mother of the Philippine Flag.
Agoncillo was a daughter of a rich family in her hometown of [[Taal, Batangas]]. Finishing her studies at [[Santa Catalina College]], she acquired her learning in [[music]] and feminine crafts. At the age of 30, Agoncillo married Filipino lawyer and jurist [[Felipe Agoncillo|Don Felipe Agoncillo]] and bore him six children. Her marriage led to her important role in Philippine history. When her husband was exiled to [[Hong Kong]] during the outbreak of the [[Philippine Revolution]], Agoncillo and the rest of the family joined him and temporarily resided there to avoid the anti-Filipino hostility of some foreign countries. While in Hong Kong, [[General Emilio Aguinaldo]] requested her to sew a flag that would represent their [[Philippines|country]]. Agoncillo, her eldest daughter and a friend manually sewed the flag in accordance with General Aguinaldo's design which later became the official flag of the Philippines.
While the flag itself is the perpetual legacy of Agoncillo,<ref name="ManilaBul"/> she is also commemorated through museums and monuments like the marker in Hong Kong (where her family temporarily sojourned), at her ancestral home in Taal, Batangas which has been turned into a museum,<ref>{{Citation |last=Culture Dept. of Education, and Sports, Philippines |publication-date=1989 |title=Duyan Ng Magiting: The Folk Culture of the Southern Tagalog Region |publication-place= |publisher=Dept. of Education, Culture, and Sports, Republic of the Philippines |page=180 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vlgeAAAAMAAJ&dq=Marcela+Agoncillo+biography&q=Marcela+Agoncillo |accessdate=2007-11-28 |isbn=978-971-10-1241-0 |year=1989}}</ref> in paintings by notable painters as well as through other visual arts.
== Early life == Agoncillo was born on June 24, 1860 in [[Taal, Batangas]], Philippines<ref>{{Citation |last=Zaide |first=Gregorio F. |publication-date= |title=Great Events in Philippine History: Patriotic Calendar |publication-place= |publisher=M. Colcol |page=107 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=J-oBAAAAMAAJ&dq=Marcela+Agoncillo+of+Taal&q=Marcela+Agoncillo |accessdate=2007-11-29 |year=1951}}</ref> to Francisco Mariño and Eugenia Coronel. She grew up in their ancestral house in Batangas built in the 1770s by her grandfather, Andres Marino.<ref name="nhi">{{cite web |url=http://www.nhi.gov.ph/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=45&Itemid=40 |title=Marcela Agoncillo Historical Landmark |accessdate=2007-11-05 |publisher=''National Historical Institute''}}</ref>
As a daughter of a rich and religious family,<ref>{{Citation |last=Mercado |first=Monina A. |publication-date=1977 |title=Profiles in Achievement |publication-place= |publisher=Philippine Appliance Corp. |page=7 |year=1977}}</ref> Agoncillo was referred to in their town as ''Roselang Hubog'' which means "a [[virgin]] enthroned in the town church". Stories told in the area related that people kept waiting patiently by the church patio for her appearance in the morning to attend mass accompanied either by a maid or an elder relative.<ref name="Geo">{{cite web |url=http://www.geocities.com/sinupan/AgonciM.htm |title=Marcela M. Aconcillo (1860-1946) |accessdate=2007-11-04 |publisher=''Yahoo Geocities''|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071028052610/http://www.geocities.com/sinupan/AgonciM.htm|archivedate=2007-10-28}}</ref>
She was sent to a convent after her education in [[Manila]]. The convent she was studying in was the [[Santa Catalina College]] of the [[Dominican Order|Dominican]] nuns, an exclusive school for girls,<ref name="delR2">{{Citation | last=del Rosario | first=Helen O. | author-link= | publication-date=June 12, 1998 | title=Marcela's feat | periodical=Philippine Daily Inquirer | publication-place= | publisher=The Philippine Daily Inquirer, Inc. | pages=D13 | url=http://www.orosa.org/Marcella_Agoncillo_by_Helen_Orosa_1.jpg | accessdate=2007-11-12}}</ref> established in the Walled City of [[Intramuros]] where she finished her elementary and secondary education. In college, she learned Spanish, [[music]], the feminine crafts and social graces.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.stacatalinacollege.edu.ph/html/history.htm |title=History of Sta. Catalina College |accessdate=2007-11-21 |publisher=''Stacatalinacollege.edu.ph''}}</ref> She spent her girlhood partly in their hometown and partly in the convent.<ref>{{Citation |last=Mercado |first=Monina A. |publication-date= |title=Profiles in Achievement |publication-place= |page=61 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NQ08AAAAMAAJ&dq=Marcela+Agoncillo+daughter+of+rich+family&q=Marcela+Agoncillo+in+Taal |accessdate=2007-11-29 |publisher=Philippine Appliance Corp. |year=1977}}</ref> Accordingly, Agoncillo was skilled in needlework.<ref name="MMA"/><ref name="FFD">{{Citation |last=de Ocampo |first=Esteban A. |last2=Saulo |first2=Alfredo B. |publication-date=1977 |title=First Filipino Diplomat: Felipe Agoncillo, 1859-1941 |publication-place= |publisher=National Historical Institute |page=170 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nxIsAAAAMAAJ&dq=Marcela+Agoncillo's+studies&q=Marcela+Agoncillo's+studies |accessdate=2007-11-28 |year=1977}}</ref><ref>{{Citation |last=de Ocampo |first=Esteban A. |last2=Saulo |first2=Alfredo B. |publication-date= |title=First Filipino Diplomat: Felipe Agoncillo, 1859-1941 |publication-place= |page=174 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nxIsAAAAMAAJ&dq=Marcela+agoncillo+giving+alms&q=Marcela+agoncillo+giving+alms |accessdate=2007-12-01 |publisher=National Historical Institute |year=1977}}</ref> [[File:Marcela Agoncillo Ancestral House.JPG|thumb|Ancestral House of Marcela Agoncillo in Taal, Batangas]]
== Marriage and family == Agoncillo was married to [[Felipe Agoncillo|Don Felipe]], a rich Filipino revolutionist and the first Filipino diplomat.<ref>{{cite news |title=National Flag Day |url=http://www.mb.com.ph/issues/2004/05/28/OPED2004052810528.html |publisher=''[[Manila Bulletin]]'' |accessdate=2007-11-05 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20050317204516/http://www.mb.com.ph/issues/2004/05/28/OPED2004052810528.html |archivedate = March 17, 2005}}</ref> They were both thirty and Don Felipe was already a judge when they finally wed. Agoncillo moved from Taal to Manila, where they lived together in a two-story house on M.H. del Pillar St., [[Malate]], near the Malate church.<ref name="delR">{{Citation | last=del Rosario | first=Helen O. | author-link= | publication-date=June 14, 1998 | title=My most memorable summer with Marcela Agoncillo | periodical=Philippine Daily Inquirer | publication-place= | publisher=The Philippine Daily Inquirer, Inc. | pages=C7 | url=http://www.orosa.org/Marcella_Agoncillo_by_Helen_Orosa_4.jpg | accessdate=2007-11-11}}</ref><ref>{{Citation |last=Agoncillo |first=Marcela Mariño |publication-date=1981 |title=Reminiscences of the Agoncillo Family |publication-place= |publisher=Garcia Pub. Co. |page=167 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zSksAAAAMAAJ&dq=Marcela+Agoncillo+early+life&q=Marcela+Agoncillo+early+life |accessdate=2007-11-28 |year=1981}}</ref>
Six daughters were born to them: Lorenza ("Enchang"), Gregoria ("Goring"), Eugenia ("Nene"), Marcela ("Celing", named after her mother because they thought she would be their last child), Adela (who died at the age of three) and the youngest, Maria ("Maring", who was their last surviving child and died on July 6, 1995). Most of her daughters became teachers. Gregoria was the first Filipina to graduate from [[Oxford University]].<ref name="delR"/> After the graduation of the three elder daughters, they were offered teaching positions. Lorenza was given an appointment to teach in Malate Catholic School.<ref>{{Citation |publication-date= |title=Reminiscences of the Agoncillo Family |publication-place= |page=42}}</ref> They so immersed themselves in their respective teaching careers that not one of them chose to be married.<ref name="delR"/> Marcella Agoncillo cared for all of her daughters until they reached maturity. One of her favorite pieces of advice to them was to "live honestly and well, and to work hard and not depend on family property".<ref name="Geo"/>
Besides the legal services rendered by Don Felipe to the impoverished,<ref name="Who">{{Citation |last=Quirino |first=Carlos |title=WHO'S WHO: In Philippine History |year=1995 |publisher=Tahanan pacific Inc. |location=Metro Manila, Philippines |isbn=971-630-046-8 |page=21}}</ref> Agoncillo and her daughters observed every Thursday as a day of charity, when a queue of needy people seeking alms would form in the Agoncillo driveway. No one ever left their house empty-handed. Agoncillo would hand them a bag of rice in addition to the money she gave them. This practice lasted until the couple retired.<ref name="delR"/>
== Living in Hong Kong == After learning of the plans of the Governor-General of the Philippines to deport Don Felipe, he sailed to Yokohama, Japan, staying there only briefly until proceeding to Hong Kong where he joined other Filipino exiles who found asylum when the revolution broke out in 1896. Twenty-two months after the departure of Don Felipe for Hong Kong, Agoncillo and the rest of the family (her last two daughters were not yet born) followed him into exile. They rented a house at 535 Morrison Hill in the [[Wan Chai district]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://members.tripod.com/paniqui_embry/alliedfam/aqwn05.htm |title=Selected Families and Individuals |accessdate=2007-11-05 |publisher=''Members.tripod.com''}}</ref> While in Hong Kong, Agoncillo gave birth to their last child on March 22, 1906.<ref name="FFD"/>
Felipe, being an exile himself, received any Filipino who came into their house. Thereafter, the place became a sanctuary for other Filipino revolutionary exiles. They initiated meetings in the Agoncillos' residence, especially during the critical months of March and April 1898. Among these folks were Gen. [[Antonio Luna]] and Gen. Aguinaldo. Also, [[Josephine Bracken]], [[Jose Rizal]]'s fiancée, sought refuge in their house when the Spanish authorities threatened to torture her.<ref name="delR2"/>
=== Making of the Philippine flag === {{further|Flag of the Philippines}}
[[File:Amorsolo's The Making of the Philippine Flag.png|thumb|right|The detail of [[Fernando Amorsolo]]'s ''The Making of the Philippine flag'' depicting Agoncillo and company's manual sewing]]
After the signing of the [[Pact of Biak-na-Bato]] on December 14, 1897, General Aguinaldo, after their voluntary exile, visited the Agoncillo residence in Hong Kong.<ref>{{Citation |last=Saulo |first=Alfredo B. |publication-date=1983 |title=Emilio Aguinaldo: Generalissimo and President of the First Philippine ... |publication-place= |publisher=Phoenix Pub. House |page=10 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4wYhAAAAMAAJ&dq=Marcela+agoncillo&q=Marcela+agoncillo |accessdate=2007-12-01 |year=1983}}</ref> After having met them, Aguinaldo requested that Agoncillo immediately hand-sew a flag according to his design which would embody the national aspirations of all Filipinos. After receiving the request, Agoncillo delegated her eldest daughter, five-year-old [[Lorenza Agoncillo]], and Mrs. [[Delfina Herbosa de Natividad]], [[Jose Rizal]]'s niece by his sister Lucia, to help her.<ref name="Intro">{{Citation |last=Agoncillo |first=Teodoro A. |title=Introduction to Filipino History |year=1974 |publisher=GAROTECH Publishing |location=Quezon City, Philippines |isbn=971-10-2409-8}}</ref><ref name="Manilatimes">{{cite web |url=http://www.manilatimes.net/national/2007/june/10/yehey/opinion/20070610opi5.html |title=A haven for Filipino patriots |accessdate=2007-11-04 |last=de Viana |first=Augusto V. |date=June 10, 2007 |work=The Sunday Times |publisher=''Manilatimes.net'' |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071125214723/http://www.manilatimes.net/national/2007/june/10/yehey/opinion/20070610opi5.html |archivedate = November 25, 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.filipinoheritage.com/history/first_flag.htm |title=The Nation's First Flag |accessdate=2007-11-21 |last=Hornedo |first=Florentino H. |publisher=''Filipinoheritage.com'' |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20071030135529/http://www.filipinoheritage.com/history/first_flag.htm <!--Added by H3llBot--> |archivedate=2007-10-30}}</ref>
The process took only a short time, but it was difficult. The three worked manually and with the aid of a [[sewing machine]]. They had to redo the flag after the rays of the sun were not in the proper direction. Their eyes and hands suffered due to the prolonged work session. Made from fine [[silk]] which she bought in Hong Kong,<ref>{{Citation |publication-date=Oct 1929 |title=The Philippine Flag, Interview with Marcela Agoncillo |publication-place=Manila |publisher=Philippine Herald|url=http://www.nhi.gov.ph/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=31&Itemid=2 |accessdate=2008-04-22}}</ref> the flag was embroidered in gold and contained stripes of blue and red and a white triangle with the sun and three stars on it.<ref name="Who"/><ref>{{Citation |last=Zaide |first=Gregorio F. |publication-date=1979 |title=The Pageant of Philippine History: Political, Economic, and Socio-cultural |publication-place= |publisher=Philippine Education Co. |page=287 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mV4bAAAAIAAJ&dq=Marcela+Agoncillo+education&q=Marcela+Agoncillo |accessdate=2007-11-29 |year=1979}}</ref> The flag was finished in five days<ref name="TPR"/> and became known as "the sun and the stars flag".<ref name="Manilatimes"/>
[[File:Agoncillo's thimble.jpg|thumb|left|The [[thimble]] used by Agoncillo in sewing the first [[Flag of the Philippines|Philippine flag]]; on display at [[Malacañan Palace|Presidential Museum & Library]].]]
On May 17, 1898, the flag was delivered personally by Agoncillo<ref name="TPR"/> and was packed among the things Aguinaldo brought back to Manila. This was the flag that was hoisted from the window of Aguinaldo's house in [[Kawit, Cavite]], during the proclamation of [[Independence Day (Philippines)|Philippine independence]] on June 12, 1898 accompanied by the Philippine National Anthem ''Marcha Filipina''.<ref name="Intro"/><ref>{{Citation |publication-date= |title=The Philippine Revolution |publication-place= |page=10}}</ref> However, she did not witness either this first public display of the flag or the time when the flag was unfurled during the [[Malolos Congress]] because her husband remained in Hong Kong and she remained with him.<ref>{{Citation |last=Mercado |first=Monina A. |publication-date= |title=Profiles in Achievement |publication-place= |page=60 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NQ08AAAAMAAJ&dq=Marcela+Agoncillo+daughter+of+rich+family&q=Marcela+Agoncillo+in+Taal |accessdate=2007-11-29 |publisher=Philippine Appliance Corp. |year=1977}}</ref>
In response to the message written by Gen. Aguinaldo, Agoncillo wrote the following statement when she was interviewed:
{{quote|In the house at 535 Morrison Hill, where I lived with my family, exiled from our country on account of the national cause, I had the good fortune to make the first Philippine flag under the direction of an illust[r]ious leader Gen. Emilio Aguinaldo y Famy...It took me five days to make that National Flag, and when completed, I myself delivered it to Gen. Emilio Aguinaldo before boarding the transport McCullo[ug]h...Gen. Aguinaldo is the best witness who can give the information whether or not that flag was the first to be displayed in Cavite at the beginning of the revolutionary government against the government of Spain in these islands.|Marcela Agoncillo<ref name="Geo"/>}}
== Post-exile and death == Agoncillo and her daughters stayed in Hong Kong from 1895 to 1906. She took care of their house, which became an asylum. Their funds had run out because of the heavy expenses incurred by Don Felipe for his diplomatic activities in France and in the United States. She once had to sell the children's pinafores<ref name="delR"/> and their jewels<ref name="delR2"/> to support her family and to pay for their voyage back to Manila. The other money was also used to help boost the revolutionary funds. Their support for the revolution made them an impoverished family; however, they gained it back when Don Felipe returned to his profession.<ref name="ManilaBul">{{cite web|url=http://www.mb.com.ph/issues/2006/06/24/OPED2006062467632.html |title=146th Birth Anniversary of Doña Marcela Mariño Agoncillo |accessdate=2007-11-21 |work=The Manila Bulletin Online |publisher=''Mb.com.ph'' }}{{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>
After the fall of the [[first Philippine Republic]] and the establishment of the American regime, Agoncillo and her family ended their exile and went back to Manila as soon as they were fetched by Don Felipe after his diplomatic activities abroad had ended.<ref>{{Citation |last=de Ocampo |first=Esteban A. |last2=Saulo |first2=Alfredo B. |publication-date= |title=First Filipino Diplomat: Felipe Agoncillo, 1859-1941 |publication-place= |page=181 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nxIsAAAAMAAJ&dq=Marcela+Agoncillo+living+in+Hong+Kong&q=Marcela+Agoncillo+living+in+Hong+Kong |accessdate=2007-11-29 |publisher=National Historical Institute |year=1977}}</ref> The Agoncillos settled in their family house in Malate. After the death of Don Felipe, Agoncillo's remaining family suffered from starvation due to their meager supply of food, water and other needs. The [[Empire of Japan|Japanese]] conquerors also contributed to their anguish during the period of the Japanese invasion.<ref name="Geo"/> Taking this all in stride, Marcela remained pragmatic and a source of inspiration. After their house was incinerated during the Japanese occupation, all she said to her remaining daughters was "We will then have to go to Taal."
Though she endured the 1945 [[Battle of Manila (1945)|Battle of Manila]], the health of Agoncillo, who was alternatively called "Doña Marcela" and "Lola Celay" during her old age,<ref name="delR"/> was steadily deteriorating. She continued to mourn her deceased husband to such an extent that her daughters found it necessary to hide all his remaining photographs.<ref>{{Citation |last=de Ocampo |first=Esteban A. |last2=Saulo |first2=Alfredo B. |publication-date= |title=First Filipino Diplomat: Felipe Agoncillo, 1859-1941 |publication-place= |page=175 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nxIsAAAAMAAJ&dq=Marcela+Agoncillo's+studies&q=marcela's+death |accessdate=2007-11-28 |publisher=National Historical Institute |year=1977}}</ref> On May 30, 1946, she quietly died in [[Manila]] at the age of 86. Her mortal remains were brought from Taal to Manila and interred alongside her husband in the [[La Loma Cemetery|Catholic cemetery of La Loma]] according to the wishes of her last will.
== Commemoration == [[File:Three Women Weaving Monument.png|thumb|''Three Women Weaving the Filipino Flag'' monument by Napoleon V. Abueva erected in [[University of the Philippines|UP campus]] to commemorate the historical sewing]] [[File:Marcela Agoncillo bust and plaque at the Historical Park.jpg|thumb|Marcela M. Agoncillo (Batangas Provincial Capitol)]] [[File:Felipe & Marcela Agoncillo historical marker at their gravesite in San Juan, Metro Manila.jpg|thumb|Historical marker in the Cemetery]] [[File:Agoncillojf3062 03.JPG|thumb| Marcela M. Agoncillo (grave in Cemetery adjoining Sancutario de Santo Cristo, [[San Juan, Metro Manila]]).]] Several commemorative [[monument|figures]] were created in remembrance of Agoncillo's historic family. On November 27, 1955, a marker was erected by the National Historical Institute of the Philippines and a [[museum]] was established in Taal, Batangas in accordance with her last wish and was named Marcela Marino Agoncillo Museum and Monument. The museum is Agoncillo's ancestral house.<ref name="nhi"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.philtravelcenter.com/philippines/travelinfo/batangas-cultural.html |title=Batangas City Travel Tips & General Informations |accessdate=2007-11-06 |publisher=''Philtravelcenter.com''}}</ref> The house-turned-museum permanently exhibits flags and a diorama depicting the sewing of the first flag. A bronze statue of her holding the flag was erected outside the house in its garden.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nhi.gov.ph/index2.php?option=com_content&do_pdf=1&id=45 |title=Marcela Agoncillo Historical Landmark |accessdate=2007-11-28 |format=PDF |work=National Historical Institute}}</ref> In Hong Kong, a historical marker was created by the Hong Kong Antiquities Council at Morrison Hill Park to commemorate the site where the first Philippine flag was sewn. However, the place where the Agoncillos resided, the location of the [[Hong Kong Junta]], and other locations of historical importance to Filipinos remain unmarked.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://skyscraperss.com/photography-heritage-architecture/94538-hk-played-key-role-rp-history.html |title=HK played key role in RP history |accessdate=2007-11-05 |publisher=''Skyscraperss.com''}}</ref>
Agoncillo's legacy is remembered through the [[visual art]]s as well. In 1996, Filipino National Artist [[Napoleon Abueva]] created the concrete and marble sculpture ''Three Women Weaving the Filipino Flag'' at the [[University of the Philippines-Diliman|UP Diliman]] to commemorate Agoncillo and the other two women who assisted her in their important task.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.filipinoheritage.com/sikatpinoy/national_artists/napoleon_abueva4.htm |title=Napoleon V. Abueva - Father of Modern Sculpture |accessdate=2007-11-05 |last=R. de la Torre |first=Visitacion |publisher=''Filipinoheritage.com'' |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20071027094443/http://www.filipinoheritage.com/sikatpinoy/national_artists/napoleon_abueva4.htm <!--Added by H3llBot--> |archivedate=2007-10-27}}</ref> Renowned Filipino painter [[Fernando Amorsolo]] painted the historical sewing and is nationally known as ''The Making of the Philippine flag''.
